{{DISPLAYTITLE:{{mp|2015 AZ|43}}}} {{Infobox planet | minorplanet = yes | background = #FFC2E0 | name = {{mp|2015 AZ|43}} | discovery_ref = | discoverer = [[Pan-STARRS]] ([[List of observatory codes#F00–F99|F51]]) | discovered = 11 January 2015 | mpc_name = {{mp|2015 AZ|43}} | mp_category = [[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]], [[Near-Earth object|NEO]] | orbit_ref = | epoch = 13 January 2016 ([[Julian day|JD]] 2457400.5) | observation_arc = 45 days | aphelion = {{Convert|2.75773|AU|Gm|abbr=on|lk=on}} (Q) | perihelion = {{Convert|0.98830226|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (q) | semimajor = {{Convert|1.87301|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} (a) | eccentricity = 0.472347 (e) | period = 2.56 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]] (936.29 [[Julian year (astronomy)|d]]) | inclination = 4.52198° (i) | asc_node = 337.42980° (Ω) | mean_anomaly = 123.5461[[Degree (angle)|°]] (M) | arg_peri = 181.78786° (ω) | dimensions = ~70 meters
50–120 meters | abs_magnitude = 23.5 | mean_motion = {{Deg2DMS|0.3844963|sup=ms}} / day (n) | rotation = {{Convert|0.59992|h|min|abbr=on|lk=on}} | uncertainty = 5 | moid = {{Convert|0.00161778|AU|km|abbr=on}} | jupiter_moid = {{Convert|2.23908|AU|Gm|abbr=on}} }} '''{{mp|2015 AZ|43}}''' (also written [[Astronomical naming conventions#Minor planets|2015 AZ43]]) is an [[List of Apollo asteroids|Apollo]] [[near-Earth asteroid]] roughly 70 meters in diameter. On 10 February 2015 with a 29.5-day [[observation arc]], it showed a 1 in 5,880 chance of [[Impact event|impacting]] Earth on 27 February 2107. However, the [[NEODyS]] [[Curve fitting|nominal]] best-fit orbit shows that {{mp|2015 AZ|43}} will be {{convert|2.8|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth on 27 February 2107. A (non-impacting) Earth close approach in 2056 makes future trajectories diverge. It was removed from the JPL [[Sentry (monitoring system)|Sentry Risk Table]] on 23 February 2015 using JPL solution 26 with an observation arc of 40 days that included radar data. With an [[Absolute magnitude#Solar System bodies (H)|absolute magnitude]] of 23.5, the asteroid is about 50–120 meters in diameter. ==2015 flyby== {{mp|2015 AZ|43}} was discovered on 11 January 2015 by [[Pan-STARRS]] at an [[apparent magnitude]] of 20 using a {{convert|1.8|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} [[Ritchey–Chrétien telescope]]. On 15 February 2015 the asteroid passed {{convert|0.0197|AU|km mi|abbr=on|lk=on}} from Earth. The [[Goldstone Deep Space Communications Complex|Goldstone Deep Space Network]] detected the asteroid on 18–19 February 2015, but the signal was not strong enough for delay-Doppler imaging. == References == {{reflist|refs= {{cite web |title=MPEC 2015-B05 : 2015 AZ43 |publisher=[[IAU Minor Planet Center]] |date=2015-01-16 |url=http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/mpec/K15/K15B05.html |accessdate=2015-02-07}} (K15A43Z) {{cite web |type=last observation: 2015-02-20; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 40 days |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2015 AZ43) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015AZ43 |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |accessdate=4 April 2016}} {{cite web |type=last observation: 2015-02-20; [[Observation arc|arc]]: 40 days |title=JPL Close-Approach Data: (2015 AZ43) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2015AZ43;cad=1#cad |accessdate=2015-02-24}} {{cite web |title=Absolute Magnitude (H) |publisher=NASA/JPL |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/glossary/h.html |accessdate=2015-02-07}} {{cite web |date=2015-02-10 |title=Earth Impact Risk Summary: 2015 AZ43 |publisher=WayBack Machine: NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/2015az43.html |accessdate=2015-02-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150210163941/http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/2015az43.html |archivedate=February 10, 2015 }} {{cite web |title=2015AZ43 Ephemerides for 25 February 2107 through 2 March 2107 |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.3.1&n=2015AZ43&oc=500&y0=2107&m0=2&d0=25&h0=0&mi0=0&y1=2107&m1=3&d1=2&h1=0&mi1=0&ti=1.0&tiu=days |accessdate=2015-02-14}} {{cite web |title=2015AZ43 close approaches |publisher=[[NEODyS]] (Near Earth Objects – Dynamic Site) |url=http://newton.dm.unipi.it/neodys/index.php?pc=1.1.8&n=2015AZ43 |accessdate=2015-02-08}} {{cite web |title=Goldstone Asteroid Schedule |publisher=NASA/JPL Asteroid Radar Research |author=Dr. [http://science.jpl.nasa.gov/people/Benner/ Lance A. M. Benner] |url=http://echo.jpl.nasa.gov/asteroids/goldstone_asteroid_schedule.html |accessdate=2015-02-20}} {{cite web |title=Date/Time Removed |publisher=NASA/JPL Near-Earth Object Program Office |url=http://neo.jpl.nasa.gov/risk/removed.html |accessdate=2015-02-24}} }} == External links == * [http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?object_id=2015+AZ43 2015 AZ43 Orbit] – ''[[Minor Planet Center]]'' * {{JPL small body|id=3703537}} {{use dmy dates|date=February 2018}} {{2015 in space}} {{Small Solar System bodies}} {{DEFAULTSORT:2015 AZ43}} [[Category:Apollo asteroids|#]] [[Category:Unnumbered minor planets]] [[Category:Asteroids removed from the Sentry Risk Table]] [[Category:Near-Earth objects in 2015|20150215]] [[Category:Astronomical objects discovered in 2015|20150111]]

page.title: A Guide to the Arrangement of British Insects

revision.text:
{{italic title}} [[Image:Curtis guide.jpg|right|250px|thumb|Page from the ''Guide'']] '''''A guide to the arrangement of British insects''''' is a [[wikt:seminal|seminal]] work of [[entomology]]. A monumental piece of work with over 10,000 insect names it was intended for the author's own use, but pressure for publication grew until it appeared in 1829. Uniquely for its time, all insect orders were included. A second was published in 1837.
Six pages of introductory matter are followed by 282 columns of insect names in two columns per page systematically arranged and followed by an index to genera. This work attributed to [[John Curtis (entomologist)|John Curtis]] was in fact co-authored by [[James Charles Dale]], [[Francis Walker (entomologist)|Francis Walker]] and [[Alexander Henry Haliday]]; Haliday and Walker writing almost the whole of the sections on Diptera and parasitic Hymenoptera. The list contains 1500 generic and 15,000 specific names. Ireland and Britain are not separated.
The full title is '''''A guide to the arrangement of British insects being a catalogue of all the named species hitherto discovered in Great Britain and Ireland'''''. The ''Guide'' had five purposes for entomologists *1st. It will enable them to arrange their Cabinets systematically. *2ndly. They may mark off their own Insects so as to know instantly whether they have a species or not, by which means their desiderata will be shown ; and this the Author is persuaded will enable Students to enrich their Cabinets by mutual exchanges to an extent which could not be accomplished by any other means. *3rdly. It will form Labels for Cabinets. *4thly. It will be a systematic Index to " [[British Entomology|The British Entomology]]’’ a reference being given to every Genus already illustrated and may be easily continued by those who are desirous of completing it. *5thly. It will be a Catalogue of the Author's Cabinet those without a * being his desiderata and of those with a J he has only foreign specimens. The names in italics denote insects which are doubtful natives.
The ''Guide'' was the subject of a celebrated quarrel between [[James Francis Stephens]] and John Curtis [[s:Quarrel between James Francis Stephens and John Curtis]]
==References== *Evenhuis, N.L., ''Litteratura Taxonomica Dipterorum'' (1758-1930). 2 vols. Backhuys Publishers, Leiden
==External links== *[https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/bibliography/46860 BHL] Digitised second edition
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Guide To The Arrangement Of British Insects}} [[Category:Entomological literature]] [[Category:1829 books]] [[Category:1829 in science]]
{{zoology-book-stub}}

revision.comment: Markx121993 moved page [[Actaea (Greek mythology)]] to [[Actaea (Greek myth)]]
revision.text:
[[File:1868 Frederic Leighton - Actaea.jpg|thumb|''Actaea, the Nymph of the Shore'' by [[Frederic Leighton]] (1853-1858)]] In [[Greek mythology]], '''Actaea''' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Ἁκταία, from ἁκτή "seashore") may refer to the following figures: * Actaea, one of the [[Nereids]]<ref>''[[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)|Bibliotheca]]'' [http://www.theoi.com/Text/Apollodorus1.html 1.2.7].</ref><ref>Hesiod. ''Theogony'', [http://www.theoi.com/Text/HesiodTheogony.html 240].</ref><ref>[[Gaius Julius Hyginus|Hyginus]]. ''Fabulae, Preface''</ref> * Actaea, one of the [[Danaids]], daughter of [[Danaus]] and [[Pieria (mythology)|Pieria]]. She married [[Periphas]], son of [[Aegyptus]].<ref>Apollodorus. ''Library'', [http://www.theoi.com/Text/Apollodorus2.html 2.1.5].</ref> * Actaea, the former name of [[Attica]]. It was renamed in honour of Atthis, daughter of Cranaus.<ref>Pausanias. ''Description of Greece'', 1.2.7.</ref>
== References == {{Portal|Greek mythology|||}}<references />{{Greek myth index}} [[Category:Nereids]] [[Category:Danaids]] [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mythological Greek characters]]

In Greek mythology, '''Astacia''' ([[Ancient Greek]]: Ἀστακίης) was a nymph whom after her Dionysus named a city.<ref>[[Nonnus]], ''Dionysiaca'' ''Book 16.405.''</ref>
== References == <references />
[[Category:Nymphs]] [[Category:Women in Greek mythology]] [[Category:Mythological Greek characters]]
{{Greek-myth-stub}}

{{Infobox Australian place | type = protected | name = Kanku - Breakaways Conservation Park | state = sa | iucn_category = iii | image = | caption = | image_alt = | coordinates = {{coord|28|50|55|S|134|43|40|E|display=inline,title}} | force_national_map = | relief = yes | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_label_position = | map_alt = | nearest_town_or_city = Coober Pedy | area = {{convert|14,323|ha|abbr=off}} | area_footnotes = | established = {{start date|2013|07|04|df=y}} | established_footnotes = {{cite web|title=Protected Areas Information System - Reserve List|url=http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/files/b88e6e26-4bd9-4c68-8fff-9e800114eb69/park-management-protected-areas-gen.pdf|publisher=Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources|accessdate=13 June 2014}} | visitation_num = | visitation_year = | visitation_footnotes = | managing_authorities = [[Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (South Australia)|Department of Environment, Water, and Natural Resources]]
Antakirinja Matu-Yankunytjatjara Aboriginal Corporation
[[District Council of Coober Pedy]] | url = }} The '''Kanku-Breakaways Conservation Park'''[https://www.environment.sa.gov.au/parks/find-a-park/Browse_by_region/flinders-ranges-outback/kanku-breakaways-conservation-park Kanku-Breakaways Conservation Park] National Parks South Australia. Accessed 20 March 2018. (prior to July 2013 called '''The Breakaways Reserve''' or just simply '''The Breakaways''') is a [[Protected areas of South Australia|protected area]] in northern [[South Australia]], just off the [[Stuart Highway]] {{convert|33|km|mi|abbr=on}} north of [[Coober Pedy]].[http://www.cooberpedy.sa.gov.au/page.aspx?u=344&t=uList&ulistId=0&c=393 District Council of Coober Pedy > Things to See & Do > Breakaways] Accessed 13 June 2014. The Breakaways CP is managed under a co-management agreement by the [[Department of Environment, Water and Natural Resources (South Australia)|Department of Environment, Water, and Natural Resources]] in conjunction with the Antakirinja Matu-Yankunytjatjara Aboriginal Corporation and the [[District Council of Coober Pedy]].[http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/new-native-title-drafted-for-south-australia/story-e6frea83-1226053991686 SA native title claim near Coober Pedy finally recognised] ''The Advertiser'', 11 May 2011. Accessed 1 September 2014.[http://www.environment.sa.gov.au/Home/Full_newsevents_listing/News_Events_Listing/130807-breakaways DEWNR > Breakaways Conservation Park to be co-managed with Aboriginal community] Press release, 7 August 2013. Accessed 13 June 2014. [https://archive.is/FPuKC Archived copy], Accessed 20 March 2018. == Name == The park got the name "''The Breakaways''" because the [[mesa]]s and low hills appear from a distance as if "broken away" from the higher ground of the escarpment. The site is significant for the [[Antakarinya dialect|Antakirinja Matuntjara Yankunytjatjara People]],[http://caama.com.au/the-breakaways-reserve Central Australian Aboriginal Media Association > The Breakaways Reserve] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714150827/http://caama.com.au/the-breakaways-reserve |date=July 14, 2014 }} Accessed 13 June 2014. whose name for the area is ''Umoona'', meaning "long life", referring to a particular species of tree found in the area.[http://www.indiginet.com.au/umoona/heritage.htm Umoona Community > The Breakaways Reserve] Accessed 13 June 2014. == Formation == == Climate == The semi-arid desert climatic conditions of the park are similar to those of [[Coober Pedy#Climate|Coober Pedy]], with cool nights and very hot days, and summer temperatures can sometimes exceed {{convert|45|°C|°F}}.[http://www.bom.gov.au/climate/averages/tables/cw_016007_All.shtml Bureau of meteorology > Climate statistics for Coober Pedy] Accessed 13 June 2014. == Access and tours == Access to the main lookout over the site is provided by a {{convert|5|km|mi|abbr=on}} dirt road from the sealed Stuart Highway, or alternatively, via the Dog Fence Scenic Tourist Drive Road. A {{convert|65.8|km|mi|abbr=on}} circuit can be made by mountain bike from Coober Pedy along the Stuart Highway to the Breakaways, along the dog fence track and returning to Coober Pedy by the Oodnadatta Track.[http://www.mapmyride.com/au/roxby-downs-south-australia/the-breakaways-lap-by-mountain-bike-route-79705701 mapmyride.com > The Breakaways lap by mountain bike route 79705701] Accessed 13 June 2014. Tours from Coober Pedy are conducted by several tour operators. Permits for self-guided visits to the area cost A$10 Per Vehicle ($8 Concession) and are available from the Tourist Information Centre in the District Council Office on Hutchinson Street, Coober Pedy.[http://www.southaustralia.com/info.aspx?id=9006797 The South Australian Tourism Commission > Breakaways] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130426185301/http://www.southaustralia.com/info.aspx?id=9006797 |date=April 26, 2013 }} Accessed 13 June 2014.[http://www.fodors.com/world/australia-and-the-pacific/australia/south-australia/coober-pedy/review-191985.html Fodor's Travel > Coober Pedy > Sights > Breakaways] Accessed 13 June 2014. {{Wide image|Coober01.JPG|800px| Mesas at the Breakaways Conservation Park|100%|center|alt=Mesas at the Breakaways Conservation Park}} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Protected areas of South Australia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Breakaways Conservation Park}} [[Category:Conservation parks of South Australia]] [[Category:Far North (South Australia)]] [[Category:Protected areas established in 2013]] [[Category:2013 establishments in Australia]]

{{coord|41.35|-93.0|region:US-IA|display=title}} '''Earthpark''' is a proposed best-in-class educational facility with indoor rain forest and aquarium elements, and a mission of "inspiring generations to learn from the natural world." It was previously called the '''Environmental Project'''.
Earthpark was to be located around [[Lake Red Rock (Des Moines River)|Lake Red Rock]], near the town of [[Pella, Iowa]].<ref name="topten"><!-- bad URL [http://www.press-citizen.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20061227/NEWS01/612270305/1079] --> ''Press Citizen'', "Top 10 news stories of 2006", December 27, 2006, retrieved on December 29, 2006.</ref> In December 2007, federal funding from the [[U.S. Department of Energy]] for the Pella location was rescinded. Proposals from a variety of potential hosts, some outside of Iowa are being considered.
== Location ==
Talks between Earthpark and the city of [[Coralville, Iowa]], the original planned location of Earthpark, ended in 2006. The project then found a new home in [[Pella, Iowa]].<ref>[http://www.press-citizen.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080902/NEWS01/809020329/1079 "Can this vision become reality?"], ''Press-Citizen'', September 2, 2008</ref> but that did not become a reality. A similar project exists in [[Cornwall, England]], called [[Eden Project|The Eden Project]].
== Size and scope == The total project cost for Earthpark is estimated to be $155 million USD. The complex was planned to be {{convert|3.5|acre|m2}} in area with a 600,000 gallon aquarium and outdoor wetland and prairie exhibits.<ref name="topten"/>
The Earthpark project was expected to employ 150 people directly and create an additional 2000 indirect jobs. The economic impact was estimated to be $130 million USD annually. The park was projected to draw 1 million visitors annually to the Pella area.<ref name="topten"/><ref name="towncrier"><!-- bad URL [http://www.towncriernews.com/pages/news/othernewsstories/earthpark.htm] --> "Pella Lands the Earthpark", ''Town Crier News'', retrieved on December 29, 2006</ref>
== Funding == In August 2008, when asked if any efforts would be made to get additional federal money for the project, U.S. Senator [[Chuck Grassley]] said "Not by this senator, and I don't think there will be any by other senators."<ref>{{cite news |date=August 26, 2008| title=Grassley frustrated with federal response to flood |author=Stephen Schmidt |publisher=''The Gazette'' |url=http://www.gazetteonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080827/NEWS/708279946/1006/news }}</ref>
== References == <references/>
== External links == * {{Official website|http://www.earthpark.org}} * {{cite news | title=Coralville rain forest loses federal funds |author=Sarah Franklin |publisher="The Daily Iowan'' |date=November 19, 2003 |url=http://media.www.dailyiowan.com/media/storage/paper599/news/2003/11/19/Metro/Coralville.Rain.Forest.Loses.Federal.Funds-561652.shtml }} * {{cite news | title= Coralville rain forest still short | author=Emily Derrico |publisher=''The Daily Iowan'' |date = March 31, 2005 | url=http://media.www.dailyiowan.com/media/storage/paper599/news/2005/03/31/Metro/Coralville.Rain.Forest.Still.Short-907621.shtml }} * {{cite news | title=The Incredible Shrinking Rain Forest: The strange odyssey of Sen. Grassley's earmark |author = Michael Judge |date= March 9, 2006 |publisher=''The Wall Street Journal'' |url=http://opinionjournal.com/cc/?id=110008064}} * {{cite news | title=Campaign Ad Calls Rainforest Wasteful Spending; Organizers Say Earthpark Will Bring In $130M Annually |url=http://www.kcci.com/news/10160032/detail.html |publisher=KCCI |date=October 25, 2006 }}

{{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Energy Market Authority of Singapore |abbreviation = EMA |logo = Energy Market Authority (logo).png |logo_width = |logo_caption = Logo of the EMA |formed = |preceding1 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Singapore]] |employees = |budget = |headquarters = 991G Alexandra Road #01-29 & #02-29 Singapore 119975 |chief1_name = Ng How Yue |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = Ngiam Shih Chun |chief2_position = Chief Executive |parent_agency = [[Ministry of Trade and Industry (Singapore)|Ministry of Trade and Industry]] |child1_agency = |website = {{url|www.ema.gov.sg}} |footnotes = }}
The '''Energy Market Authority''' ('''EMA''') is a [[Statutory boards of the Singapore Government|statutory board]] under the [[Ministry of Trade and Industry (Singapore)|Ministry of Trade and Industry]] of [[Singapore]]. EMA's main goals are to promote [[effective competition|effective]] [[competition]] in the [[energy market]], ensure a reliable and secure [[energy supply]], and develop a dynamic energy sector in Singapore.
== Liberalization of Retail Electricity Market<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ema.gov.sg/electricity_market_liberalisation.aspx|title=EMA : Liberalisation of Retail Electricity Market|website=www.ema.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-01}}</ref> ==
Since 2001, EMA has progressively opened the retail electricity market to competition to allow business consumers more options to manage their energy cost. Instead of buying from SP Group at the regulated tariff, eligible consumers can choose to buy from a retailer at a price plan that best meet their needs, or buy from the wholesale electricity market at the half-hourly wholesale electricity prices. Those who exercise this choice are termed as contestable consumers.
Currently, business consumers with an average monthly electricity consumption of at least 2,000 kWh (equivalent to a monthly electricity bill of at least $400) are eligible to become contestable. Currently, about 95,000 business accounts, making up about 80% of the total electricity demand, are eligible to exercise this choice and flexibility in their electricity purchases.
Since 1 April 2018, EMA commenced the soft launch of Open Electricity Market, where households and businesses in Jurong can choose to buy electricity from a retailer at a price plan that best meets their needs.
From 1 November 2018, the Open Electricity Market will be extended to all consumers across Singapore by zones. This initiative will provide about 1.4 million households and business accounts with more choice and flexibility when buying electricity, while being provided with the same electricity supply through the national power grid.
Consumers who wish to remain with SP Group and buy electricity at the regulated tariff can choose to do so, and no further action is needed on their part. It is not compulsory to switch to a retailer and there is no deadline for switching.
== See also == * [[Renewable energy]]
==External links== *[http://www.ema.gov.sg/ Energy Market Authority Home Page] {{Government of Singapore}}
[[Category:Energy in Singapore]] [[Category:Statutory boards of the Singapore Government]] [[Category:Energy regulatory authorities]]
{{Singapore-stub}}
